title-group.article-title: In Vivo Kinematics of the Talocrural and Subtalar Joints With Functional Ankle Instability During Weight-Bearing Ankle Internal Rotation
title-group.subtitle: A Pilot Study

article-meta.aff: Graduate School of Medical Technology and Health Welfare Sciences, Hiroshima International University, Higashi Hiroshima, Japan (TK)
Department of Rehabilitation, Imamura Orthopaedic Clinic, Nagasaki, Japan (YN)
Department of Rehabilitation, Kobayashi Hospital, Kitami, Japan (KY)
Department of Rehabilitation, Sadamatsu Hospital, Oomura, Japan (MS)
Department of Integrated Rehabilitation, Hiroshima International University, Higashi Hiroshima, Japan (KG)

author-notes.corresp: Kazuyoshi Gamada, PhD, PT, Department of Integrated Rehabilitation, Hiroshima International University, 555-36 Kurose Gakuendai, Building 1, Room 705, Higashi Hiroshima, Hiroshima, 739-2695, Japan; e-mail: kazgamada@ortho-pt.com.

abstract.p: Functional ankle instability (FAI) may involve abnormal kinematics. However, reliable quantitative data for kinematics of FAI have not been reported. The objective of this study was to determine if the abnormal kinematics exist in the talocrural and subtalar joints in patients with FAI. Five male subjects with unilateral FAI (a mean age of 33.4 ± 13.2 years) were enrolled. All subjects were examined with stress radiography and found to have no mechanical ankle instability (MAI). Lateral radiography at weight-bearing ankle internal rotation of 0° and 20° was taken with the ankle at 30° dorsiflexion and 30° plantar flexion. Patients underwent computed tomography scan at 1.0 mm slice pitch spanning distal one third of the lower leg and the distal end of the calcaneus. Three-dimensional (3D) kinematics of the talocrural and subtalar joints as well as the ankle joint complex (AJC) were determined using a 3D-to-2D registration technique using a 3D-to-2D registration technique with 3D bone models and plain radiography. FAI joints in ankle dorsiflexion demonstrated significantly greater subtalar internal rotation from 0° to 20° internal rotation. No statistical differences in plantar flexion were detected in talocrural, subtalar or ankle joint complex kinematics between the FAI and contralateral healthy joints. During ankle internal rotation in dorsiflexion, FAI joints demonstrated greater subtalar internal rotation. The FAI joints without mechanical instability presented abnormal kinematics. This suggests that abnormal kinematics of the FAI joints may contribute to chronic instability. FAI joints may involve unrecognized abnormal subtalar kinematics during internal rotation in ankle dorsiflexion which may contribute to chronic instability and frequent feelings of instability.
Level of Evidence: Diagnostic, Level IV, Cross-sectional

disp-quote.p: “With a potential combined instability of the talocrural and subtalar joints being suspected, detailed measurements of abnormal kinematics of the 2 joints are required.”

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lateral ankle sprain (LAS) is one of the most common injuries in competitive sports and recreational activities. Ankle injuries are accounted for 10% to 30% of all athletic injuries and for 40% to 56% of injuries in certain sports.1 Ankle sprains were accounted for 70% or more of ankle injuries in many sports.1 Symptoms of ankle sprain often remain, because athletes with ankle sprain often return to sports without consulting a medical personnel.2 Reported recurrent rate of the ankle sprain was as high as 56% to 74%.3-5 Predominant symptoms are pain and crepitus for people with 1 to 3 reinjuries, and unstable feeling for people with 4 or more reinjuries.5 Repetition of the ankle sprain leads to chronic ankle instability.6

In a conventional classification, the cause of chronic ankle instability would be either MAI7 or functional ankle instability (FAI).6 MAI is, by definition, caused by ligament laxity,8-10 whereas FAI is caused by the other reasons, including proprioceptive deficits,11-13 neuromuscular deficits,14-16 postural control deficits,17-20 and muscle weakness.11,21,22 Clinical diagnosis of MAI relies on stress radiography involving increased talar anterior translation or increased talar varus,23 and joint laxity of the talocrural and subtalar joint to the other degrees of freedom is not taken into consideration. In contrast, the cause of FAI has not been fully understood.2,24 Subjects with FAI walked with the ankle in greater inversion than in subjects without FAI.25,26 In addition, ankle inversion in the FAI joint was greater than that of the non-FAI joint before initial contact during drop jump and lateral hop landings.27,28 Therefore, abnormal ankle kinematics do exist in the FAI joints, and involvement of joint laxity in the other degrees of freedom is further suspected. However, past in vivo kinematic studies with surface markers involved soft tissue artifacts29 and could not evaluate kinematics of the talocrural and subtalar joints separately. With a potential combined instability of the talocrural and subtalar joints being suspected, detailed measurements of abnormal kinematics of the 2 joints are required. The objective of this study was to determine if the abnormal kinematics exist in the talocrural and subtalar joints in patients with FAI.

The maximal dorsiflexion of the ankle is considered stable because of bony conformity and is known as the close-packed position.30,31 Therefore, subtalar joint would be with relatively greater mobility in dorsiflexion. On the contrary, the ankle is considered more unstable in plantar flexion in which LAS is thought to occur. Therefore, it was speculated that foot strike with increased subtalar inversion could result in ankle sprain.32 Recent case reports suggested LAS occurred in ankle internal rotation and inversion in dorsiflexion.33,34 Thus, LAS may cause instability not only in the talocrural joint but also in the subtalar joint, which may also be a reason for future reinjuries.

We hypothesized that (a) the FAI joints in dorsiflexion demonstrate greater inversion of the subtalar joints during ankle internal rotation and (b) the FAI joints in plantar flexion demonstrate greater internal rotation and inversion of the talocrural joints during ankle internal rotation. To test the hypotheses, we used a 3-dimensional to 2-dimensional (3D-to-2D) registration technique in this cross-sectional study.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: This study was approved by the local institutional review board (IRB) and compared the kinematics between the FAI and contralateral healthy joint of the same subject as the control. All subjects met specific selection criteria. Inclusion criteria were (a) healthy males, (b) history of at least 2 episodes of unilateral LAS, (c) multiple episodes of feelings of instability, (d) having unilateral ankle instability, (e) report of instability, and/or weakness in the involved ankle, (f) current tendency for the ankle to give way during sporting activities, and (g) side-to-side difference in side hop test.35 Exclusion criteria were (a) history of LAS in the past 3 months; (b) swelling and feeling severe pain in the past 3 months; (c) history of cerebropathy, neuropathy, and lower extremity injury in the past 3 months; (d) experience of receiving rehabilitation program, including balance exercise for the involved ankle; and (e) evidence of MAI by stress radiography of the talocrural (anterior drawer >3 mm, talar tilt >3°) and subtalar (talocalcaneal tilt >5°) joints.23 Five male subjects with unilateral FAI (age = 33.4 ± 13.2 years; mass = 70 ± 9.8 kg; height = 172.2 ± 5.9 cm) participated in this study. All subjects read and signed the IRB–approved informed consent form before participation.

sec.title: A 3D-to-2D Registration Technique
sec.p: In vivo 3D positions and orientation of the tibia/fibula, talus, and calcaneus were determined using a 3D-to-2D registration technique using a custom software program JointTrack (http://www.sourceforge.net/projects/jointtrack). It requires static radiography and computed tomography (CT)–based bone models to obtain kinematics of the talocrural and subtalar joint.36,37 Previously reported procedures with manual matching, then automated matching using nonlinear least squares technique were used.36,38 Kinematics were determined from 3D positions of each bone model using Cardan angles.39 The estimated accuracy of this matching method for the knee joint was 0.53 mm for in-plane translations, 1.6 mm for an out-of-plane translation, and 0.54° for rotations.38,40 Similar accuracy would be expected in the ankle measurements. The average interobserver differences for the ankle kinematics were 2.2 mm for out-of-plane translations and 1.8° for rotations.37 The average intraobserver differences were 2.0 mm and 1.8°, respectively.

sec.title: Radiography
sec.p: Subjects underwent lateral radiography (Hitachi Medical Corp, Tokyo, Japan) for the bilateral ankles. Subjects stood in a lunge position with the forward foot fixed onto a tilted footplate on a turntable (Figure 1). Positions of the ankle involved (a) 0° internal rotation at 30° dorsiflexion, (b) 20° internal rotation at 30° dorsiflexion, (c) 0° internal rotation at 30° plantar flexion, and (d) 20° internal rotation at 30° plantar flexion. An examiner instructed the subjects with testing procedures and measured ankle positions during testing using a goniometer.

caption.p: Turntable settings. Forward foot fixed onto a turntable on a tilted footplate. Lateral radiography of the ankle was taken with the ankle 0° and 20° internal rotation in both ankle dorsiflexion and plantar flexion.

sec.title: Computed Tomographic Images and Geometric Bone models
sec.p: Subjects underwent CT scan (Pro speed F2, GE HealthCare Japan, Tokyo, Japan) at 1.0 mm slice pitch spanning from distal one third of the lower leg to the distal end of the calcaneus. Geometric bone models of the tibia/fibula, talus, and calcaneus were created from CT images. Exterior cortical bone edges in the images were segmented using commercial software (3D-Doctor, Able Software, Lexington, MA), and these point clouds were converted into polygonal surface models (Geomagic Studio, Geomagic, Research Triangle Park, NC).

sec.title: Anatomical Coordinate Systems
sec.p: Anatomical coordinate systems were embedded in each bone model following the method of Yamaguchi et al37 using a custom software program (VH KneeFitter; Figure 2). This anatomical coordinate system was reported with the average interobserver difference in translation being 0.35 mm and in rotation being 0.76°, and the average intraobserver differences were 0.35 mm and 0.85°, respectively.37

list-item.p: Tibial coordinate system: On the cross-sectional slices of the CT images of the distal tibial shaft at 5 and 10 cm above the joint surface, the geometric center points were obtained in each slice. The line connecting these 2 points was defined as the superoinferior axis. The origin was defined as the intersection of the tibial plafond and the superoinferior axis. The anteroposterior axis was defined as the line perpendicular to the superoinferior axis and the line passing though the origin and parallel to the line connecting the anteromedial and anterolateral edges of the tibial plafond. The mediolateral axis was the cross product of the superoinferior and anteroposterior axes.

Talar coordinate system: First, the midpoint of anteromedial and anterolateral edges and the midpoint of posteromedial and posterolateral edges of the trochlea tali were defined. Then, a circle on the sagittal plane fit to the trochlea was drawn so that the 2 midpoints are on the circle. The origin was defined as the center of the circle, and the mediolateral axis was defined as the line perpendicular to the circle and passing through the origin. The anteroposterior axis was defined as the line parallel to the line connecting the anterior and posterior edge of the trochlea on the circle, passing through the origin. The superoinferior axis was formed as the cross product of the anteroposterior and mediolateral axes.

Calcaneal coordinate system: The line connecting the most lateral point of the posterior articular surface and the most medial point of the middle articular surface was drawn, and the center of the line was defined as the origin. The superoinferior axis was defined as the line perpendicular to this line and the line tangent to the inferior surface of the calcaneus. The mediolateral axis was defined as the line perpendicular to the superoinferior axis and the lateral wall of the calcaneus, passing though the origin. The anteroposterior axis was the cross product of the superoinferior and mediolateral axes.

caption.p: Anatomical coordinate system of the bones. Medial and inferior views of the tibia as well as the medial and superior views of the talus and calcaneus are shown. Reference points (orange circle) and lines (yellow dotted lines) were shown in the figure. AP; anteroposterior axis, ML; mediolateral axis, SI; superoinferior axis.

sec.title: Outcome Measures
sec.p: Kinematics of the talocrural and subtalar joint as well as the ankle joint complex (AJC) were expressed as motion of the talar origin relative to the tibial coordinate system, the calcaneal origin relative to the talar coordinate system, and the calcaneal origin relative to the tibial coordinate system, respectively. Inversion–eversion was defined as the rotation along the anteroposterior axis, internal–external rotation was rotation along the superoinferior axis, and plantarflexion–dorsiflexion was the rotation along the mediolateral axis.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: Wilcoxon signed-rank test was used to compare kinematics of the healthy and FAI joints. All data were analyzed with the Statistical Program for the Social Sciences software (PASW Statistics 18, SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL). Differences were considered statistically significant where P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: No statistical difference was detected in talocrural inversion, internal rotation, or subtalar inversion (Table 1). FAI joints in ankle dorsiflexion demonstrated significantly greater subtalar internal rotation from 0° rotation to 20° internal rotation (healthy, 0.53° ± 3.67°; FAI, 5.20° ± 3.67°; P = .043, Table 1, Figure 3). No statistical difference was detected in talocrural, subtalar or AJC kinematics between the FAI and healthy joints in plantar flexion (Table 1).

caption.p: Comparisons of Displacements in the Healthy and FAI Joints During 20° Ankle Internal Rotation at 30° Dorsiflexion and 30° Plantar Flexion

fn.p: Abbreviations: FAI, functional ankle instability; AJC, ankle joint complex ; D/F, dorsiflexion; Ev., eversion; Int., internal rotation; Ant., anterior translation; Sup., superior translation.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Significant difference between FAI and healthy joints (P < .05).

caption.p: Talocrural and subtalar internal rotation during 20° ankle internal rotation at 30° dorsiflexion.

*Functional ankle instability (FAI) joints demonstrated significantly greater internal rotation in the subtalar joint (P < .05), whereas no statistical difference was detected for the talocrural joint.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The objective of this study was to determine if the abnormal kinematics exist in the talocrural and subtalar joints in patients with FAI. As a result, FAI joints demonstrated significantly greater subtalar internal rotation from 0° rotation to 20° internal rotation in ankle dorsiflexion. No statistical difference was detected between the FAI and healthy joints in plantar flexion.

This study compared the kinematics in both ankle dorsiflexion and plantar flexion between the FAI and healthy joints in weight-bearing conditions in vivo. There are only a few previous studies that provide comparable data for this study. Regarding talocrural kinematics, Caputo et al41 reported, using biplane fluoroscopic registration technique, that MAI joints demonstrated significantly greater talocrural anterior translation and internal rotation than that of the intact joints. Excision of the anterior talofibular ligament in vitro increased anterior translation and internal rotation of the talus, and additional excision of the calcaneofibular ligament made the tendency more emphasized.42-46 As for the subtalar kinematics, Kamiya et al47 showed that excision of the calcaneofibular ligament increased subtalar internal rotation when external rotation torque was applied to the shank. Similarly, in the present study, the FAI joints demonstrated significantly greater subtalar internal rotation in weight-bearing ankle internal rotation. However, contradictory to our results, Ishii et al48 indicated, using plain radiography, supination in ankle maximum dorsiflexion increased subtalar anterior translation relative to the talus in patients with recurrent ankle sprains. The present study did not fully support the results of these previous studies assumingly because the testing conditions were different and the enrolled ankles were not classified as MAI. In ankle dorsiflexion, the talus in the FAI joint did not demonstrated increased internal rotation. It would be because the talocrural joint was more stable in dorsiflexion than that of the subtalar joint and, therefore, the subtalar motion was predominant.31 In plantar flexion, no differences were detected in either the talocrural or the subtalar joints. It would be because both the talocrural and subtalar joints are mobile in plantar flexion and the tested position was within the normal range of motion. These results may be associated with the static testing conditions and future study should involve dynamic testing. In summary, the FAI joints, which presumably are free from ligamentous failure, may involve abnormal kinematics in the subtalar joint in ankle dorsiflexion, and this may be because of unknown mechanical instability.

A 3D-to-2D registration technique using lateral fluoroscopy or radiography is a well-established technique to measure dynamic weight-bearing knee kinematics in vivo with standard errors within 1.6 mm for translations and 0.54° for rotations.38 All subjects had unilateral FAI by stress radiography and performance tests. The testing positions were standardized by using the custom rotating platform on the tilting board. In addition, there were no statistical differences in AJC dorsiflexion and internal rotation angles. Accordingly, we believe this study is carried out with high internal validity. As for the external validity, since this study intended for young, healthy males who did not have osteoarthritis, these results may not be applicable to females or elderly people with osteoarthritis.

This study has some limitations. Since the method used in this study involves larger error in out-of-plane or mediolateral translation,40 we excluded it from our results. Sample size was small and may involve beta errors. We have not measured limb length discrepancy and internal disease with potential for ligamentous laxity. Furthermore, since this study used quasi-static testing conditions for kinematic analyses, it may not have reproduced natural and dynamic kinematics in FAI joints.

In conclusion, increased subtalar internal rotation in ankle dorsiflexion during static ankle internal rotation was found in FAI joints. It may be associated with unrecognized MAI, which have not been captured by conventional stress radiography. We do not know if it is a cause of recurrent feelings of instability in this cross sectional study. Therefore, further dynamic and longitudinal study is needed to determine if unrecognized MAI with subtalar instability is the cause of recurrent feelings of instability. Clinically, if patients without mechanical laxity in talocrural joint repeat feelings of instability, this unrecognized subtalar mechanical instability might be associated with feelings of instability. Accordingly, ankle orthosis or taping intended for stabilized subtalar joints might effective for these patients.
